statement:
Let $n$ be the order of a finite cyclic group $G$. For every positive
$m$ of $n$, there exists one and only one subgroup of order $m$ of $G$.
The group $G$ has no other subgroups.\
*Proof.* If $g$ is a generator of $G$ and $n = mk$, then $g^k$ generates
the subgroup $\langle g^k\rangle$, the order of which is equal to the
order of $g^k$, i.e. equal to $m$. Any subgroup $H$ of $G$ is cyclic
(see ). If $|H| = m$, then $H$ must have a generator of order $m$; thus
apparently $H = \langle g^{\pm k}\rangle = \langle g^k\rangle$.
